message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of internal hemorrhoids, and the prolapsing mass is likely a hemorrhoid. Treatment usually involves increasing fiber intake and stool softeners, hence docusate therapy is the most appropriate next step in management. Topical diltiazem is used in the treatment of anal fissures. Propranolol is used in the treatment of hypertension and is not appropriate in this case. Hemorrhoidectomy is a surgical option and is not the first-line treatment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest internal hemorrhoids, and conservative management is usually the first-line treatment. Docusate therapy can help soften the stool and alleviate straining during defecation, which can worsen the bleeding. Topical diltiazem and propranolol are used to manage anal fissures and hypertension, respectively, and are not indicated in this case. Hemorrhoidectomy is a more invasive treatment option and is usually reserved for cases of severe or recurrent hemorrhoids that do not respond to conservative management.

Docusate therapy can help soften the stools and reduce straining during defecation, which can reduce the bleeding. Topical diltiazem and propranolol are used to treat anal fissures and high blood pressure, respectively, which are not indicated in this case. Hemorrhoidectomy is a surgical option for severe or persistent symptoms, but is not the first-line choice.

Docusate therapy is appropriate to soften the stools and prevent further trauma to the hemorrhoids. Topical diltiazem and propranolol are used to treat hemorrhoids, but not in the acute phase. Hemorrhoidectomy is typically reserved for severe or unresponsive cases.

Topical diltiazem is used for anal fissures and propranolol is used for hypertension caused by pheochromocytoma, which are not applicable in this case. Hemorrhoidectomy is a surgical option for severe and persistent symptoms, but should not be the first line of treatment.
